text: The monster roared, the rocky plates on its limbs glinting faintly green under the light. Each step it took made the ground tremble.
I watched its movements carefully, trying to find a pattern. It was fast and heavy, scattering pebbles with every step. My heartbeat quickened.
I thought I saw an opening and shouted, “Alicia! Its left leg—” But before I could finish, the beast lunged the other way.
I couldn’t dodge in time. The force of the blow sent me sprawling. The world spun as leaves and dirt filled my vision.
Then, in a flash of silver, Alicia surged forward, brushing past the creature as her blade cut cleanly across its neck.
The beast let out a shrill screech, stiffened, and then crumbled to ash. The scent of scorched earth hung heavy in the air.
Flat on my back, I gasped for breath. Alicia hurried over, kneeling beside me with a frown. “What were you thinking? A monster like this—only a seasoned fighter can predict its moves.”
I couldn’t find words. She sighed, her tone softening. “It’s fine. I’m not blaming you. Just… don’t try to handle it alone next time. Leave it to me.”
She tore a strip of cloth and gently wiped the blood from my arm, her movements quiet and precise. Her expression softened as she murmured, “Does it hurt?”
“I can handle it.” I grinned. “Next time, I’ll get it right.”
She pressed her lips together, sounding half helpless, half amused. “You just can’t help showing off.”
The wind rustled through the forest as she looked toward the scorched earth, her expression gradually calming.
“It’s not a natural creature. It’s a ‘Residual Dream’—a trace left behind by the dead.”
“Yes. In places where wars were fought and people died, the ground keeps their final emotions. Over time, those emotions take shape.”
Then she added softly, “Don’t scare me like that again, alright?”
I blinked, then chuckled. “Was that… concern?” She shot me a glare but didn’t answer, instead offering me her hand.
“Come on. The market’s just ahead,” she said. “We’ll get you some medicine once we’re back in town.”
